attributes.title: Understanding community attitudes towards stool donation
attributes.description: This study aims to understand community attitudes towards, motives for, and barriers preventing stool donation; willingness to donate stool; bowel habits; and factors that may impact the success and experience of donating stool outside the home environment.

q1.value: Understanding community attitudes towards stool donation

q2.value: Melissa K. Hyde, Barbara Masser, Donor Research Network (DoRN)

q3.value: Faecal Microbiota Transplantation (FMT) of donated stool (poo) is a vital treatment for patients with recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (bacteria inflames the colon causing chronic diarrhoea and sometimes death) when antibiotics are ineffective. FMT can cure up to 90% of these patients. Stool banks rely on volunteers to donate stool for FMT. However, recruiting donors is challenging and costly. There are no Australian, and few international, studies on community attitudes, motives, barriers, and willingness for stool donation, or information about bowel habits, that could inform donor recruitment and logistics in stool banks. Therefore, we propose to address these gaps in understanding by surveying the Australian community (potential donors) about their attitudes, motives, and willingness for stool donation as well as barriers and facilitators of donation.

q4.value:
This study is exploratory in nature and is designed to understand community attitudes towards, motives for, and barriers preventing stool donation; willingness to donate stool; bowel habits; and factors that may impact the success and experience of donating stool outside the home environment. The following aspects will be explored in the survey:
1.	Bowel habits.
2.	Knowledge of FMT and C. difficile.
3.	Willingness and intentions to donate stool.
4.	Attitudes, social norms, and self-efficacy towards donating to a stool bank.
5.	Motives for donating to a stool bank.
6.	Facilitators and barriers to donating to a stool bank.
7.	Willingness to receive FMT if needed to treat illness.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will use a cross-sectional quantitative research design via an online survey with a panel of Australian participants to obtain their perspectives on stool donation, bowel habits, and factors that may impact stool donation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Eligible participants will: be aged 18 years or older; Australian citizens; believe they are in good health with no current medical conditions; believe they are of normal weight; are not currently taking medication for a medical condition; and do not currently have a chronic digestive disorder or condition that may affect how often they do a bowel movement. 

Participants will be invited to the study via Prolific Academic’s online panel (limited to the Australian cohort). Participants will be asked to provide a unique identifier as per Prolific rules to ensure they can be appropriately compensated in a way that maintains participant anonymity. Once they have signed up to the study, participants will be presented with a participant information sheet and consent mechanism, followed by the survey questions, and debrief sheet, all of which will be administered to participants via an online survey platform such as Qualtrics. It is anticipated that the survey will take approximately 25 minutes in total to complete. Once completed, participants will be compensated for their time as per Prolific Academic requirements.

q13.value: We will aim for a sample of at least 600 participants, that is 50% male, 50% female in composition and that comprises participants of a range of ages.

q14.value:
Based on Cohen’s conventions for effect sizes, we adopted a small to moderate f value of 0.1, to determine the required sample size for the study. Based on an estimated effect size of f = 0.10 with a specified alpha level of .05, a power level of 0.90, and an estimated 15 predictors for multiple regression analysis, the total required sample size is a minimum of 249 participants.

Given that this study is exploratory in nature, and in order to allow exploratory analyses on the basis of gender, age or another characteristic, as well as to account for attrition and missing data, we aim to recruit 600 participants (i.e., 300 each for males and females) to complete the survey.

q15.value: If the Prolific Academic online panel does not have the required number of participants to meet our target sample size, we will seek an ethics amendment to extend our recruitment protocol to include student and community samples.

question.value: Not applicable

The full survey has been added to the Project and will be fully accessible when the project is made public.

Where possible, the survey will include measures from the previously published study on stool donation[6] or established measures in other related contexts adapted to the topic of the current study. Specifically, the survey will include questions about:
•	Participant characteristics: age, gender, ethnicity, highest education level, height and weight (for the purposes of calculating BMI which is used as criteria for screening potential stool donors), perceived eligibility to donate blood, blood donor status, and organ donor registration status.
•	Bowel habits: frequency, timing and duration of BMs;[11,19,26] comfort using public restrooms to do BMs.[24] 
•	Knowledge: awareness of FMT and C. difficile;[11] preferred types of information to inform decisions about stool donation.[27]
•	Willingness to donate stool (to a stool bank, for research purposes), including frequency and duration willing to donate;[11] intentions to donate stool in the future.[28]
•	Attitudes towards donating stool to a stool bank: general attitudes,[28,29] ambivalence,[30] disgust.[31] 
•	Social norms: approval from close others.[28]
•	Self-efficacy: beliefs about how easy or difficult it would be to become a stool donor.[28]
•	Motives for donating to a stool bank: altruism (reluctant, self-referent, impure, kin, warm glow),[32] personal involvement (e.g., family or friends with chronic digestive issues, knowing someone who has had C. difficile or needed FMT),[33] contributions to science/knowledge,[34,35,36] public service motivation.[37]
•	Facilitators and barriers to donating to a stool bank: open-ended questions.
•	Willingness to receive FMT if needed to treat illness.[11]
Please refer to the analysis plan

Descriptives 
Participant age, bowel habits (duration of BM, Q2), willingness to donate (Q6-9, Q12-14), knowledge (Q17), motives (Q19-21), attitudes (Q24-26), social norms (Q27-29), self-efficacy (Q30-32), intention to donate in future (Q33-35), and willingness to receive FMT if needed (Q36) will be analysed using descriptive statistics, including means, standard deviations, and range.  
Responses to demographic questions (gender, ethnicity, education), other types of donation (blood donation, organ donor registration), bowel habits (BM regularity, frequency, consistency, timing; Q1-2), knowledge (Q4-5), frequency and duration of willingness (Q9-11), and general attitude (Q19-20) will be analysed using descriptive statistics, including counts and percentages. 
Participant’s BMI will be computed by dividing their weight (kg) by height (metres squared). Once calculated the following guidelines will be used to determine classification: < 18.5 = underweight, 18.5 – 24.9 = healthy weight range, 25-29.9 = overweight, ≥30 = obese.[38]

Factor analysis
Exploratory factor analysis will be conducted on responses to Q19, Q20, Q21 and Q25. If the results of this analysis indicate that appropriate composite scales can be created that are internally reliable (determined by Cronbach’s alpha of >0.70) then composite scales representing responses to these questions will be generated.

Regression analysis
In order to understand the key factors predicting willingness and intention to donate, Q17-21 and Q24-36 will be subject to hierarchical multiple regression, with a significance value cut-off of p ≤ 0.05. Demographic characteristics such as age, gender, blood donor history may also be included in regression models.

q21.value: p value ≤ 0.05 wil be used to determine significance. Should significant differences be observed in ANOVAs or MANOVAs then these will be followed up with the appropriate post hoc analysis (e.g., Tukey HSD) with a Bonferroni correction made to the p value for multiple comparisons.

q22.value: Should outliers be identified, analyses will be run with and without the outlier(s) to establish their influence on assumptions and/or results and this will be reported on. The outlier(s) may be transformed and if necessary may be excluded from the analysis, and will depend on the nature of the outlier(s).

q23.value: Participants with missing data on quantitative scales will be excluded for analyses.

q24.value:
Exploratory analysis
Responses to bowel habits, motives, attitudes, willingness etc. will also be explored as a function of a range of demographic characteristics (e.g., gender, age, blood donor status etc).  This will be conducted in order to advance our understanding of demographic characteristics that may impact bowel habits and people’s decisions to donate to universal stool banks. Analyses may include chi-square analysis, one-way ANOVA, or MANOVA. Should significant differences be observed in ANOVAs or MANOVAs then these will be followed up with the appropriate post hoc analysis (e.g., Tukey HSD) with a Bonferroni correction made to the p value for multiple comparisons.

Thematic analysis
Free-text qualitative responses to Q3, Q15, Q16, Q18, and additional comments, and responses to the ‘other’ or ‘please specify’ option in demographic questions (gender, ethnicity, education, Q9-11) will be coded by the investigators using content or thematic analysis.[39]

q25.value:
The Project Protocol has been added and will be available when the Project becomes public.

Contact: For further information about this project please contact Mel Hyde (m.hyde@uq.edu.au)

Ethics: This study received Human Ethics Research Committee approval from The University of Queensland on the 23rd January 2020.

summary.value:
January 24, 2020

We are uploading this document as an amendment to our study preregistration (available at https://osf.io/shdr3), which we uploaded on January 7, 2020.

As our preregistration outlines, we will recruit a total of 300 participants for this study. We began data collection on January 11, 2020. As of this writing, on January 24, 2020, we have collected data from 45 participants.

We are amending our preregistration with the following two additions:

1) We hypothesize that our three expected effects—compared to dairy ice cream (control condition) participants, participants who are told they are eating vegan ice cream will (1) rate the ice cream as tasting worse, (2) eat less of the ice cream, and (3) be less likely to want to purchase the ice cream at a store—will be moderated by prior consumption of vegan ice cream, such that these effects will be larger among participants who had not eaten vegan ice cream prior to our study than among participants who had eaten vegan ice cream prior to our study. We will conduct three separate ordinary least squares regressions to test whether the effect of ice cream type on each outcome is moderated by prior consumption. We will separately regress each outcome on prior consumption, ice cream condition, and the interaction term for prior consumption and condition. We will assess prior consumption with the question, “Have you ever eaten vegan ice cream in the past?” with responses including “yes” and “no.”

2) Participants will be excluded from analyses if they voice accurate suspicions about the study’s aims.

attributes.title: Effects of personality on immersion: Do personality factors moderate the relationship between technological immersion and attitude change?

q1.value: Effects of personality on immersion: Do personality factors moderate the relationship between technological immersion and attitude change?

q3.value: Virtual reality is often described as an empathy machine, allowing users to experience events through others’ eyes (Bevan et al., 2019); this can lead to increased empathy (Shin, 2018) and changes in attitudes and feelings of responsibility (Aitamurto et al., 2018). Much of virtual reality’s power as a persuasive technology can be related to immersion, or the state of being present in the experience presented by virtual reality media (Bailey et al., 2015). However, recent research has suggested that immersion is not simply ‘experienced’ by the viewer, and an be affected by traits including trait empathy (Shin, 2018). This project aims to see if other personality variables related to immersion, including three of the ‘Big Five’ personality traits (extraversion, openness and neuroticism; Wiebel et al., 2010), immersive tendency (Hou et al., 2012) and the social values of self-direction and stimulation (Schwartz et al., 2012) moderate the relationship between immersion and attitude change when watching a non-fiction documentary (either in VR or desktop). The focus will be on attitudes towards the homeless; the documentary is called Life on the Streets of San Fransisco by KQED News.

q4.value:
H1: Directional. There will be greater change in attitudes towards the homeless in the high immersion condition (head-mounted display) than the low immersion condition (desktop).

H2: Non-directional. The traits of openness to experience, neuroticism, and extraversion will significantly moderate the relationship between immersion and attitude change.

H3: Non-directional. Immersive tendency will significantly moderate the relationship between immersion and attitude change.

H4: Non-directional. The values of stimulation and self-direction will significantly moderate the relationship between immersion and attitude change.

H5: As the levels of each of the personality variables increases in the high immersion condition, attitude change will increase.

For H1 and H5, it is expected that this attitude change will reflect reduced attitudes that a homeless individual is responsible for homelessness, as explained later in this form.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

The independent/predictor variable is level of technological immersion (low/high) when watching the documentary which is the between-subjects element. There are six moderating variables (self-direction and stimulation values; openness, extraversion and neuroticism traits; immersive tendency). The one outcome variable is attitude change towards the homeless, represented as changes in attitudes that a homeless individual is responsible for homelessness. There is a pre-test element where participants fill out the personality measures and the attitude survey, and a post-test element where, after watching the documentary, they fill out the attitudes questionnaire again.

This will be assigned randomly using https://www.random.org/, except for the case where one condition receives considerably more participants - some participants will be placed in the other condition to provide equal sample sizes.

question.value:
Participants will be obtained from a population at the University of Bath in the UK, likely to be mostly students. Recruitment will be performed via posts on social media by the lead researcher, recruitment emails sent via the Department of Psychology, and adverts posted on noticeboards where allowed. No payment will be made for participation, however participants will be entered into a prize draw to win a £25 Amazon voucher. 
There is an exhaustive list of exclusion criteria, these are
•	Participant who have suffered from epilepsy, have a family history of epilepsy, febrile convulsions in infancy or recurrent fainting spells 
•	Participants fitted with a heart pacemaker, cochlear implant, medication pump or surgical clip 
•	Participants who are pregnant 
•	Participants who are under 18 
•	Participants under the influence of alcohol 
•	Participants who have previously watched ‘Life on the Streets of San Francisco’ (was previously used in a second-year research project) 
•	Participants who have experienced homelessness or have a family member who is or was homeless 
•	Participants with a history of nausea or motion sickness 
•	Participants who have experience a recent injury to eyes, face, neck or arms that would prevent comfortable use of the Oculus Go. 
•	Participants who have hearing problems 
•	Participants who are transplant patients or who have had a stroke 
•	Participants who do not understand the goals or the study and those who do not provide informed consent 
•	Participants under the influence of alcohol 
The study aims to run from 28th January 2020 until early April 2020.

q13.value: The target sample size is 100 participants, with no ‘upper limit’ for when participant recruitment will end. There will be around 50 participants per condition.

q14.value: The software program G*Power was used to conduct a power analysis. The goal was to obtain .8 power to detect a medium effect size of .25 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. This gave a sample size of 92 which was rounded up to 100.

q15.value: Data collection will cease on Monday 6th April 2020 to allow time to write the report for the masters’ dissertation due in early May.

question.value:
Manipulated variable: Technological immersion: two levels
•	High immersion, represented by the use of a virtual reality headset or head-mounted display to view the documentary, the Oculus Go.
•	Low immersion, represented by the use of a desktop with VLC Player to view the documentary on a HP Pavilion laptop.
These variables are consistent in other ways, such as the way participants hear sound (same headphones) and that videos in both conditions are both navigable in 360-degrees.

Moderators:
Personality traits: Extraversion, openness to change and neuroticism measured on a 5 point scale (1 – strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree). Measured using the 10 item version of the IPIP Neo-PI-R domains questionnaire (Costa & McCrae, 1992). 30 items total, 10 for each trait. 

Values. Stimulation and self-direction (including self-direction-action and self-direction thought) measured on a 6 point scale (1 = not at all like me, 6 = very much like me). Measured using the Portrait Values Questionnaire (PVQ-5X; Schwartz et al., 2012). 9 items total. 6 items for self-direction and 3 items for stimulation.

Immersive tendency. Measured on a 7 point scale. Uses a few different endpoints (e.g. 1 = Never, 7 = Often, 1 = Not At All, 7 = Very Well). Measured using the Immersive Tendencies Questionnaire (Witmer & Singer, 1998). 18 items total. 

Outcome variable: 
Attitudes towards the homeless. Specifically, the attitude that it is the individuals’ responsibility for homelessness is measured, as the documentary concerns individual experiences of homelessness. Measured on a 5 point scale (1 = Strongly Disagree, 5 = Strongly Agree). Measured using the ‘Individual Responsibility’ subscale of the Systems and Individual Responsibility for Poverty scale (SIRP; Shor et al., 2018). The scale has been revised by the author and all references to poverty are replaced by ‘homelessness’. 8 items out of 17 items total on the full questionnaire. Measured twice (before watching video and after watching video).

Other measured variables that will not be used in the main analyses but are kept as variables of interest is the level of presence (measured using the Igroup Presence Questionnaire, Schubert et al., 2001, 13 items), and the other half of the SIRP scale, measuring ‘System Responsibility’ for homelessness (9 items).

The means for each of the scales (values, personality traits, immersive tendency, attitude, etc.) will be used to create single measures for each of these factors.

Attitude change will be calculated by subtracting the mean score on the pre-test attitudes survey from the mean score on the post-test attitudes survey. For example, if a participant had a post-test attitudes score of 4 and a pre-test score of 3, this leaves an attitude change score of +1. This score can also be negative (e.g. pre-test = 4, post-test = 3, score = -1.)

An independent samples t-test will be used for H1. The independent variable is the level of technological immersion (low/high), and the outcome variable is change in attitudes towards the homeless. 
The statistical model used for H2 – H5 will be moderated regression. Six single moderated regressions will be performed, as detailed below. All moderated regressions will be performed using the PROCESS macro for SPSS. 
1. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: self-direction value, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
2. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: stimulation value, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
3. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: openness to change personality trait, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
4. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: extraversion personality trait, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
5. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: neuroticism personality trait, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
6. Predictor: Technological Immersion (low/high), moderator: immersive tendency, outcome: change in attitudes towards the homeless.
If interaction effects are found simple slopes analysis will be performed to uncover the nature of moderation.
Simple slopes analysis will be performed via the PROCESS macro for SPSS, which uses t-tests to judge the effect of the predictor (immersion) on the outcome (attitude change) at different levels of the moderating variable. Additionally, the Johnson-Neyman output will be explored through PROCESS, which allows a researcher to see at which boundaries of the moderator the relationship between the predictor and outcome variables are significant.

q20.value:
Immersion will be dummy coded to produce a dichotomous predictor variable for moderated regression: those in the low immersion condition (desktop) will receive a value of 0, and those in the high immersion condition (VR) will receive a value of 1. 
The personality trait questionnaire will require reverse coding due to some questions being reverse-coded. 
All variables will be mean-centred prior to use in the moderated regression. This will be done using a feature built in to the PROCESS macro.

q21.value: The standard p < .05 criteria will be used for determining if the regression and t-test results are significantly different than those expected if the null hypothesis were correct. Where appropriate, two-tailed analyses will be performed.

q22.value: No checks will be performed besides verification that subjects answered all the scales provided. Outliers will be included in analysis.

q23.value: If a subject is missing data in any of the moderating variables or the attitudes measure, the subject will not be included in analysis.

q24.value:
It is expected that some of the personality measures, particularly the trait and value measures, may relate to immersive tendency (Wiebel et al., 2010) so correlations will be run between these factors to determine their relation. 
Whilst the focus of the documentary is on individuals and their situation, and thus effects are expected to be found in terms of attitudes towards individual responsibility for homelessness, the effects on attitudes that the system (e.g. the state, police etc.) is responsible for homelessness may also be explored. 
Lastly, the effects of presence, which is used to verify whether those in the high immersion condition were more present or ‘immersed’ than those in the low immersion condition, may also be explored, such as its relationships with personality variables and attitude change.

registration_responses.q3: Virtual reality is often described as an empathy machine, allowing users to experience events through others’ eyes (Bevan et al., 2019); this can lead to increased empathy (Shin, 2018) and changes in attitudes and feelings of responsibility (Aitamurto et al., 2018). Much of virtual reality’s power as a persuasive technology can be related to immersion, or the state of being present in the experience presented by virtual reality media (Bailey et al., 2015). attributes.title: Humanness From Color
attributes.description: Examining the dynamic influences of skin tone and racial category in attributions and perceptions of positive qualities.

q1.value: Humanness From Color – Examining the Influence of Perceived Femininity

q3.value:
-	Past research has investigated the extent to which a person’s race moderates the degree to which social perceivers attribute traits that reflect humanness to them (Haslam, 2006).  These traits refer to emotional, cognitive, or behavioral characteristics that differentiate humans from other animals or from machines (such as robots). In addition to the overall effect of skin tone (with lighter skin resulting in higher ratings of human qualities), data collected in previous studies demonstrated some heterogeneity in the results across different stimulus faces. Certain faces were seen as having pronouncedly more positive human qualities when their skin tone was lighter, whereas perceptions of other faces were much less influenced by changes in skin tone.  In post hoc, exploratory analyses, we saw that this heterogeneity covaried with the degree of target facial femininity, in accord with some recent research suggesting that people implicitly associate lighter skin tones with women (Carrito & Semin, 2019).  

We extend our examination of this research question using similar methods to our previous studies, by systematically manipulating (and morphing) a series of Black and White male faces taken from the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015). This method for producing stimuli allowed us to examine the effect of different skin tones on the same target image.  In this new study, we will specifically select a new set of face stimuli that are either low or high in relative facial femininity, to directly test whether a target’s facial femininity does indeed moderate the effect of skin tone as it relates to the attribution of human qualities.

q4.value:
-	All hypotheses are driven by evidence suggested by our previous studies, our subsequent post hoc investigations, and the existing literature. The hypotheses focus on the relation between facial skin tone group (as manipulated – lighter vs. darker) and both the targets' racial category and perceived femininity in predicting the positivity of social evaluation. 
-	Based on our previous findings, we expect no overall race bias in evaluations, such that both Black and White targets will be evaluated equivalently in terms of their human qualities.
-	Based on prior literature showing that women are generally rated as having more positive qualities than men (e.g., Eagly & Mladinic, 1994), we hypothesize that independent of race and skin tone, faces higher in feminine features will be rated as having more positive human qualities than faces lower in femininity.  
-	Based on our previous findings, we predict that faces with lighter skin tones will be seen has having more human qualities than faces with darker skin tones. 
-	We predict that this main effect of skin tone will be qualified by an interaction with degree of facial femininity.  Specifically, the effect of lighter (vs. darker) skin tones in creating higher ratings of positive human qualities will be much stronger in the subset of faces that are lower in facial femininity.  That is, the effect of skin tone on attributions of positive human qualities will be significantly attenuated among faces that are higher in facial femininity.
-	Finally, based on our previous findings, we predict that the magnitude of race bias (per participant) will correlate with the participant's political ideology. Additionally, we predict that the magnitude of skin tone bias will not correlate with the participant’s political ideology.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: -	All of the theoretically significant variables in our study design (i.e., target race, target skin tone, and target facial femininity) will be manipulated within-subject, thus, even though participants will not be explicitly informed about the design or the importance of the different target stimuli they evaluate, they will experience all experimental conditions. Participants will be blind to the methodological factors (counterbalancing condition and stimulus set) of the design.

question.value: Overall, the experiment is a five-way fully factorial mixed design. Three variables are manipulated within participants (target skin tone: light or dark; target race: white or black; target femininity: high or low). Two methodological variables are manipulated (by random assignment) between participants (stimulus set: 1, 2, or 3; counterbalancing condition: A or B). The stimulus set variable involves three different sets of facial stimuli to be rated, with faces in each set reflecting all 8 combinations of target skin tone, target race, and target facial femininity. The purpose of this variable is to examine the generalizability of the results across different stimuli. The counterbalancing variable involves manipulating which particular faces in a given stimulus set are lightened and which ones are darkened. The half that are lightened in Set A will be darkened in Set B, and vice versa. In this way, no participant will be asked to rate different versions of the very same face, yet over the entire experiment, each face will be rated approximately equally often in its lightened and darkened versions.

q9.value: -	As previously mentioned, there are two methodological factors that create 6 between-participant conditions (stimulus set: 1, 2, or 3 × counterbalancing condition: A or B). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of these 6 conditions.  Within each of these conditions, participants will be exposed to all 8 possible combinations of the 3 theoretically central, within-participant manipulations of target race (Black or White), target skin tone (lighter or darker), and target facial femininity (low or high).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: -	To obtain a large enough sample that provides a diverse set of participants and high-quality data, participants will be recruited online via MTurk. Users will self-select to participate from a list of tasks posted to the marketplace. A short description of the study will be posted on MTurk. Compensation will be determined based on the typical completion time of pilot participants, prorated from a base of $10 per hour. To be eligible for the study, participants must be English-speaking American adults who respond correctly to a two-question “bot-check” – screening questions that are easy for English-speaking humans to answer, but which are difficult for computer programs to guess.

q13.value: -	We will recruit 300 MTurk workers to participate in our study, with an aim to have a final sample of at least 250 usable participants after exclusions.

q14.value: -	Due to the type of multilevel statistical models we employ, assessments of power using conventional methods are not straightforward. Thus, we base our sample size intentions on previous studies that we have run, for which this number of participants has been adequate to detect meaningful effects (see https://osf.io/g8v32/).

question.value:
-	Our three manipulated theoretical variables are target skin tone, target race, and perceived femininity of the target. Target race is manipulated by selecting male faces that are tagged as African American or as White in the Chicago Face Database. We used faces with neutral facial affect and a direct, camera-facing pose.  The two levels of perceived femininity will be operationalized by norming data associated with each target face in the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015) norming data. High-femininity targets were created using faces that were rated in the highest quartile on perceived femininity for their respective racial group, whereas low-femininity targets were created using faces in the lowest quartile of perceived femininity. To reduce idiosyncratic facial features, we morphed pairs of faces that fell into the same race-by-femininity category to create the stimulus faces. That is, pairs of faces that were identified as high-feminine Black men in the face database were morphed together, as were faces identified as low-feminine Black men, as high-feminine White men, and as low-feminine White men. This procedure was intended to create faces that more prototypically (less idiosyncratically) embody the qualities of race and facial femininity. All morphs were created using the FantaMorph by Abrosoft photo morphing software. 
-	The two levels of the skin tone variable will be operationalized by digitally manipulating each of the morphed target images into both a lightened skin tone and a darkened skin tone version using Adobe Photoshop. Faces in the group consisting of Black targets with lightened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 135, faces in the group consisting of Black targets with darkened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 60, faces in the group consisting of White targets with lightened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or very near 175, and faces in the group consisting of White targets with darkened skin tone have Adobe Photoshop (CC 2018) Luminosity values at or above 100. 
-	As previously described, there are also two methodological variables. The stimulus set variable involves creating three different sets of facial stimuli to be rated by participants; in each set, the procedures outlined above were used to create 8 different kinds of stimuli reflecting all possible combinations of race, skin tone, and facial femininity. The counterbalancing variable involves manipulating which particular faces in a given stimulus set are lightened and which ones are darkened. The half that are lightened in Set A will be darkened in Set B, and vice versa.

-	Our primary outcome variables are:
-	1. Based on our previous studies we will collect ratings of each face in terms of 4 positive human qualities: polite, thorough, curious, and friendly (Haslam et al., 2005). Participants will be asked how well the traits fit each face on a 0 (not at all) to 100 (very much) sliding scale. 
-	2.  In addition to the trait-based dehumanization items we will include a one-item measure of trustworthiness also assessed on a 0 to 10 sliding scale.
-	Our demographic variables are Age, Education, Gender Identity, Race/Ethnicity, Sexual Orientation, Political Ideology and we collected participants' immediate reactions to the study, including a question on whether they took the study seriously.

-	Several composite indices will be computed for analysis:
1. For each face, we will compute the mean attribution of positive human traits (polite, thorough, curious, and friendly) in each of the conditions. Thus, each score will be the mean of 4 items.  Because perceived trustworthiness has not been previously examined in this program of research, and because of its central role in social perception (e.g., Todorov, Said, Engell, & Oosterhof, 2008), we will analyze it separately from the other 4 traits.  
2. We will compute a summary index of each participant’s overall tendency to show colorism bias, by subtracting (for the composite variable outlined above) their mean rating of the darker group of faces from their mean rating of the lighter group of faces. We will compute a summary index of each participant’s overall tendency to show a race bias by subtracting (for the composite variable outlined above) their mean rating of the Black faces from their mean rating of the White faces.  For exploratory purposes, we will also compute a summary index of each participant’s overall tendency to show a femininity bias by subtracting (for the composite variable outlined above) their mean rating of the low femininity faces from their mean rating of the high femininity faces.  If the 4-item composite rating of positive human qualities is highly correlated with ratings of trustworthiness (r  .75), we will include the ratings of trustworthiness in the composites used to create these indices; otherwise, we will also create separate indices of skin tone, race, and femininity bias based on the trustworthiness ratings.

-	All analyses will be conducted using partially cross-classified multilevel modeling. In these models, we will include two random intercepts: a random intercept of participant (which adjusts for the fact that observations are nested within person), and a random intercept of stimulus image (which adjusts for the fact that observations are nested within stimuli). These models will be conducted by regressing our dependent variables onto within-person contrasts codes. One contrast will test whether lighter-skinned targets are judged differently than darker-skinned targets (light = 0.5, dark = -0.5); another contrast will examine whether white targets are judged differently than black targets (white = 0.5, black = -0.5); the final will examine whether targets perceived as high in femininity are judged differently than targets perceived as low in femininity (high = 0.5, low = -0.5). In addition, we will examine each two-way interaction (Target Race × Target Skin Tone, Target Race × Target Femininity, and Target Skin tone × Target Femininity) and the three-way interaction (Target Race × Target Skin Tone × Target Femininity).

q21.value: -	We will use the conventionally accepted statistical inference criteria of Null Hypothesis Significance Tests, with a two-tailed alpha specified at .05.

q22.value:
-	One of the final questions of our survey asks participants to report whether or not they took the study seriously (with no consequences for their compensation). We will exclude any participants who explicitly respond that they did not take the study seriously.  
-	Also, we will rely on guidelines for identifying and excluding outliers as suggested by Leys et al., 2019. Thus, we will correct or delete obvious erroneous values, and use the Median Absolute Deviation method to identify univariate outliers. We will exclude any participants who qualify as multivariate outliers according to the Minimum Covariance Determinant method. Subsequently, we will run all analyses both including all data points and with univariate outliers excluded. Any changes  that result from outlier inclusion/exclusion for our research findings will be explicitly noted in research reports.  
-	In addition, because data quality deteriorates when participants spend too much time off-task in the middle of an experiment (e.g., multitasking; see Clifford & Jerit, 2014), we will use excessively long survey completion times as a basis for participant exclusion.  In a pilot test of our procedures, we determined that participants took an average of approximately 5 minutes to complete the survey and few needed more than 6 minutes.  As a conservative indicator of excessive off-task activity, we will exclude any participants whose survey completion times exceed 15 minutes (i.e., 3x the average time taken in the pilot test).

q24.value: -	We will examine whether patterns of skin tone, race, and facial femininity bias are moderated by political ideology, age, or gender.

registration_responses.q1: Humanness From Color – Examining the Influence of Perceived Femininity
registration_responses.q3:
-	Past research has investigated the extent to which a person’s race moderates the degree to which social perceivers attribute traits that reflect humanness to them (Haslam, 2006).  These traits refer to emotional, cognitive, or behavioral characteristics that differentiate humans from other animals or from machines (such as robots). In addition to the overall effect of skin tone (with lighter skin resulting in higher ratings of human qualities), data collected in previous studies demonstrated some heterogeneity in the results across different stimulus faces. Certain faces were seen as having pronouncedly more positive human qualities when their skin tone was lighter, whereas perceptions of other faces were much less influenced by changes in skin tone.  In post hoc, exploratory analyses, we saw that this heterogeneity covaried with the degree of target facial femininity, in accord with some recent research suggesting that people implicitly associate lighter skin tones with women (Carrito & Semin, 2019).  

We extend our examination of this research question using similar methods to our previous studies, by systematically manipulating (and morphing) a series of Black and White male faces taken from the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Correll, & Wittenbrink, 2015). This method for producing stimuli allowed us to examine the effect of different skin tones on the same target image.  In this new study, we will specifically select a new set of face stimuli that are either low or high in relative facial femininity, to directly test whether a target’s facial femininity does indeed moderate the effect of skin tone as it relates to the attribution of human qualities.
registration_responses.q4:
-	All hypotheses are driven by evidence suggested by our previous studies, our subsequent post hoc investigations, and the existing literature. The hypotheses focus on the relation between facial skin tone group (as manipulated – lighter vs. darker) and both the targets' racial category and perceived femininity in predicting the positivity of social evaluation. 
-	Based on our previous findings, we expect no overall race bias in evaluations, such that both Black and White targets will be evaluated equivalently in terms of their human qualities.
-	Based on prior literature showing that women are generally rated as having more positive qualities than men (e.g., Eagly & Mladinic, 1994), we hypothesize that independent of race and skin tone, faces higher in feminine features will be rated as having more positive human qualities than faces lower in femininity.  
-	Based on our previous findings, we predict that faces with lighter skin tones will be seen has having more human qualities than faces with darker skin tones. 
-	We predict that this main effect of skin tone will be qualified by an interaction with degree of facial femininity.  Specifically, the effect of lighter (vs. darker) skin tones in creating higher ratings of positive human qualities will be much stronger in the subset of faces that are lower in facial femininity.  That is, the effect of skin tone on attributions of positive human qualities will be significantly attenuated among faces that are higher in facial femininity.
-	Finally, based on our previous findings, we predict that the magnitude of race bias (per participant) will correlate with the participant's political ideology. Additionally, we predict that the magnitude of skin tone bias will not correlate with the participant’s political ideology.

attributes.title: Guidelines for laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research: Consensus report of an international Delphi survey
attributes.description: We aim to synthesize responses from an expert Delphi panel to create a set of statements offering guidelines for the determination and reporting of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research

q1.value: Guidelines for laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research: Consensus report of an international Delphi survey

q3.value: Large variation in determination and reporting of laterality indices exist in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. These differences make between-study comparison difficult and hinder meta-analytic approach. By inviting international experts in laterality research over a wide range of behavioral and neuroimaging methods and have them create and rate statements on best practices in determination and reporting of laterality indices we aim to reach consensus on basic guidelines. We will apply an iterative and anonymous method to achieve this aim known as the Delphi method.

q4.value: We anticipate obtaining reasonable agreement by this method for a fair number of statements describing good practices for laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are blinded for the raters’ responses, and all raters are also unaware of the responses of the other raters.

question.value:
Cohort study on good practices using laterality indices
The design involves an online Delphi panel aiming to achieve a consensus document regarding (a) guidelines for the valid and reliable determination of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research and (b) guidelines for reporting laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. 
Each panel will adopt an iterative approach and involve a multidisciplinary group of international experts.
For the online Delphi process, we will largely follow the methods documented by Bishop et al. (2015, 2017). Statements for evaluation will be generated individually by a panel of experts. Two moderators for each method will review the statements to remove doubles. The lists of statements will then be sent to the expert panels for rating. Participants will be asked to rank each item twice on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from strongly against to strongly in favor, once for relevance (i.e., should a statement on this theme/topic be included in our guidelines) and once for validity (i.e., to what extent do you agree with the statement as currently worded). Participant responses will be collated and the distribution of scores examined. Statements that score low on relevance will be omitted from future rounds. Online discussion will be invited for statements rated as relevant where there is disagreement as to the validity. Following this discussion, a second set of statements will be drawn up and circulated for ranking again. If necessary, this whole process can be repeated, but in practice Delphi panels seldom achieve further agreement after three rounds of rating. Items that are rated as both valid and reliable will be collated into a consensus statement.

q9.value: Participants are not selected randomly. All are experts in one or more methods of laterality determination as evidenced by publications listed in WoS and who agree to our invitation.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants are recruited by invitation only. The list of invitees is based on authorships of scientific publications on brain or behavioral asymmetries in Web of Science. Invitees are asked to name other experts in their field that could contribute to the consensus document. New names are checked for their publications in WoS before invitation. Participants are not paid for participation but will be named as a contributor to the consensus document.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 experts. We aim to have at least 5 experts for each method.

question.value:
Experts will be asked to individually formulate statements they think useful in determination and reporting of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. Statements will be sent in anonymously via an online link. Two moderators for each method will review these statements, remove doubles, and make a list. Statements will not be changed at this point. 
These statements will serve as ‘stimuli’ and fed back to the panel of experts for rating.
Outcome variables will be the ratings on agreement and relevance of the statements by the panel of experts. Ratings will be performed on 5-point-Likert scales.
Descriptive statistics will be used to document the ratings of the experts.

q25.value:
Study objectives
1. To identify a set of statements about guidelines for reliable and valid determination of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. 
2. To identify a set of statements about guidelines for reporting laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. 
3. To synthesize responses from an expert Delphi panel to arrive at a draft set of statements 
giving guidelines on the application and reporting of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research.
4. To disseminate these draft guidelines to audiences in academia and the general public.

Guy Vingerhoets is leading author. Theme moderators will serve as co-authors. Contributors will be listed as consensus signees.

For the online Delphi process, we will largely follow the methods documented by Bishop et al. (2015, 2017). Statements for evaluation will be generated individually by a panel of experts. Two moderators for each method will review the statements to remove doubles. The lists of statements will then be sent to the expert panels for rating. Participants will be asked to rank each item twice on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from strongly against to strongly in favor, once for relevance (i.e., should a statement on this theme/topic be included in our guidelines) and once for validity (i.e., to what extent do you agree with the statement as currently worded). Participant responses will be collated and the distribution of scores examined. Statements that score low on relevance will be omitted from future rounds. Online discussion will be invited for statements rated as relevant where there is disagreement as to the validity. Following this discussion, a second set of statements will be drawn up and circulated for ranking again. If necessary, this whole process can be repeated, but in practice Delphi panels seldom achieve further agreement after three rounds of rating. Items that are rated as both valid and reliable will be collated into a consensus statement.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants are recruited by invitation only. The list of invitees is based on authorships of scientific publications on brain or behavioral asymmetries in Web of Science. Invitees are asked to name other experts in their field that could contribute to the consensus document. New names are checked for their publications in WoS before invitation. Participants are not paid for participation but will be named as a contributor to the consensus document.
registration_responses.q16.question:
Experts will be asked to individually formulate statements they think useful in determination and reporting of laterality indices in human behavioral and neuroimaging research. Statements will be sent in anonymously via an online link. Two moderators for each method will review these statements, remove doubles, and make a list. Statements will not be changed at this point. 
These statements will serve as ‘stimuli’ and fed back to the panel of experts for rating.
registration_responses.q17.question: Outcome variables will be the ratings on agreement and relevance of the statements by the panel of experts. Ratings will be performed on 5-point-Likert scales.
registration_responses.q19.question: Descriptive statistics will be used to document the ratings of the experts.

attributes.title: Biracial Women as Identity-safe Cues_Study 3_the importance of specific signaling

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Biracial women as Identity-safe Cues: Exploring whether signaling a Black or White identity impacts White-Black biracial women acting as identity-safe cues for Black women.

other.value:
We will look at correlations between all the primary outcome variables. If belonging, trust and comfort, and affective organizational commitment are highly correlate, we may create a z-score composite to assess “anticipated trust and belonging” at the company. Moreover, if organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions are highly correlated, we also may create a z-score composite to examine “attraction” to the company. 
We will run exploratory analyses to examine whether stigma consciousness moderates any of our results. We also will run exploratory mediation analysis to examine whether there is an indirect effect of condition on identification via perceptions that the scientist had similar experiences with past adversity, and whether these is an indirect effect of condition on anticipated belonging at the company via identification.

sample.value: 500 Black female participants will be recruited for this experiment. This number was determined from an a priori analyses using G*Power and partial η-squared = 0.036 effect size. This effect size was taken from a previous experiment using a similar manipulation and outcome variables. We recruited a higher number of participants than we estimated requiring, to account for exclusion due to failed attention checks (described in the next question), and excluding any Black women identify as biracial. Moreover, because we were not including a mono-racial Black woman condition, and had subtle variation between the biracial conditions, we reasoned our effect size might be smaller in the current experiment.

analyses.value: We will run between-subjects ANOVAs, and Tukey HSD postdoc tests to examine differences between conditions.

outliers.value: We only included women who identify as monoracial Black in our final sample. Participants will complete 3 easy attention check questions about the article, and we will exclude participants who fail to answer these questions. As a second attention check, at the end of the study we will ask participants to briefly describe what they did as part of this study. We will exclude participants who put nonsensical answers (e.g., “impressive” “very nice study” “prime survey ideas”).

dependent.value:
Monoracial Black female participants will begin the experiment by being presented with a fictional company called “LabTech”. Participants will then be assigned to one of 4 company profile conditions. Specifically, participants will learn about a scientist working at the company who is either a monoracial White woman (as a comparison condition), or a racially ambiguous White Black biracial woman who does not signal her identities, who only signals her White identity or who only signals her Black identity. That is, in the biracial “signaling” profile, the scientist will explicitly discuss having a White or Black parent. Importantly, prior to reading the profile, all participants in the “non-signaling” and “signaling” biracial conditions will learn that this employee is biracial. 

Next, participants will complete a series of measures assessing their impressions of the scientist in the company profile. Specifically, participants will indicate a) the extent to which they believe the scientist has faced past bias, b) the extent to which they think the scientist has had similar experiences of adversity and similar experiences generally as themselves, c) their sense of self-other overlap and identification with the scientist, d) the extent to which they believe the scientist looks similar to themselves, and e) the extent to which the scientist is loyal to and wants to help Black women.

Participants in the three biracial conditions also will complete a measure assessing the extent to which they believe the scientist identifies strongly with her Black woman identity (i.e., complete a measure of identity centrality), and will complete an index measuring how much they think the scientist would try to “pass” as White.  

All participants will then be presented with the LabTech website a second time, and asked to imagine how they would feel being an employee at the company. Participants will then indicate their anticipated belonging, trust and comfort, and affective organizational commitment at the company, and organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions for the company.  Finally, participants will complete measures assessing their gender race stigma consciousness (i.e., their concern about being devalued because of their race and gender).

conditions.value: There will be four conditions –White woman, Biracial woman who signals she is Black, Biracial woman who signals she is White, and Biracial woman who does not signal.

hypothesis.value:
The primary goal of this experiment is to explore when and why monoracial Black women do or do not identify with a White Black biracial woman who appears racially ambiguous and whether she in turn encourages belonging in a STEM company. In particular, this experiment will explore whether monoracial Black women identify more with a racially ambiguous biracial woman when she clearly signals in her company profile that she is half Black or avoids mentioning her race relative to when she clearly signals in her company profile that she is half White (i.e., could be trying to “pass” as White).

Previous research has found that Black women identify more strongly and anticipant more belonging in a STEM environment with a Black female scientist compared to a White female scientist. However, in recent work, we also have found that when a racially ambiguous biracial scientist signals she has a Black and White parent, Black women participants identify equally well with this biracial scientist as they do with a Black woman scientist. However, in our previous studies, the biracial scientist never act as though she was trying to pass as White. Specifically, by mentioning her White (and not Black) ancestry, the biracial scientist might appear like she is trying to pass as White.

Thus, we hypothesize that compared to Black female participants who learn about a biracial female scientist who signals her Black racial identity or doesn’t signal, those who learn about a biracial female scientist who signals her White identity or a White female scientist, will think the scientist has faced less bias, will believe the scientist has had fewer similar experiences, will identify less strongly with the scientist, and will anticipate less belonging and be less interested in working at the scientist’s company.  Moreover, we predict that Black women will perceive the biracial scientist who only signals her White identity as caring less about Black women, as identifying less strongly as a Black woman, and as being more likely to “pass” as White relative to the biracial woman who does signal.
